In the case of damage related to care but which has occurred without any breach of professional or scientific rules or error, this is known as no-fault liability.

The legislator has recognised compensation systems for which liability may be incurred on the basis of an event other than proven fault. This is the case with nosocomial infections.

question.title: What type of liability is incurred when damage occurs due to a nosocomial infection without any breach of professional or scientific rules or error?

option_a.title: Fault-based liability
option_a.description: A type of liability that requires proof of fault or negligence

option_b.title: No-fault liability
option_b.description: A type of liability that does not require proof of fault or negligence

option_c.title: Strict liability
option_c.description: A type of liability that holds the healthcare provider responsible for any damage, regardless of fault or negligence

option_d.title: Proximate cause liability
option_d.description: A type of liability that holds the healthcare provider responsible for damage caused by a proximate cause

correct_option.title: B
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the correct option
